Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Patient-Specific and Conventional Instrumentation in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 100 patients undergoing TKA were randomised

Participants.evidence: The study was conducted at a single orthopedic center, with participants recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either patient-specific instruments (n=50) or conventional instruments (n=50)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the precision and reliability of patient-specific CT-based instrumentation in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to conventional instrumentation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of outliers in postoperative hip-knee-ankle angles, measured within 6 weeks post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 patients undergoing TKA were randomised to receive either patient-specific instruments (n=50) or conventional instruments (n=50)

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was performed on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Outliers in hip-knee-ankle angles were 12% in the patient-specific group and 10% in the conventional group (p=0.75).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported in either group.
